title: Prue Leith reveals her top tip for cutting down on plastic in the kitchen
text:
From Country Living

Prue Leith – famous for her vibrant style, Bake Off prowess and entrepreneurial success – will appear as a guest of honour at the Country Living Christmas Fair, London on Wednesday 13th November.

In exiting news, Prue will join Country Living editor-in-chief Susy Smith on stage, to talk about food, Christmas and her life in the Oxfordshire countryside. Following the live interview at 12pm on the first day of our annual London fair, Prue will be hosting a book signing of her latest title Prue: My All-Time Favourite Recipes.

BUY FAIR TICKETS For 25% off, see info at bottom of the page.



Before meeting her at the Fair, Country Living caught up with Prue for a chat...

PRUE ON PLASTIC

Why did you get involved with the #MyPlasticFeedback campaign?

Because it's so important.

What annoys you most about plastic?

Mostly, I get in a rage walking around the supermarkets finding everything in still wrapped in plastic.

How do you reduce plastic in the kitchen?

I used to put cling film over everything but now I use those stretchy, elasticised tops that you get from Lakeland. They're very cheap and they're reusable and they're much easier than trying to stretch the clingfilm. BUY NOW, £2.29, Lakeland

PRUE ON BAKE OFF

You’re now judging your third Great British Bake-Off: do you feel like an old hand?

Every year’s different but I definitely feel more relaxed now. In the first one, I think I was quite tentative, but now I know Paul much better, we get on very well and I’m so fond of him. Sandi and I have also become firm friends and Noel is just lovely: he’s so unpredictable and larky and quirky – it’s like having a huge puppy around the place. But the first day I met Sandi, I remember feeling unnerved, thinking, ‘My god, she’s such a star and she’s so clever.’

Would you say that you and Paul have different judging styles?

Yes – he’s incapable of brushing over a fault. Sometimes if I feel really sorry for someone, I never lie, but I might tone it down a bit. But what’s so interesting is that Paul and I always have the same opinion of the makes. We usually have a rough number out of ten in our heads and it’s always the same. We’ve only disagreed once the whole time I’ve been on the show.

What are your favourite dishes to judge?

I think we all prefer the savoury ones because there is so much sweet. Sugar’s great if you haven’t had it for a while but we have it every day. So when we get savoury pie day, it’s absolute heaven.

Photo credit: Channel 4 More

What impresses you most about the Bake-off contestants?

How confident they are, not just in baking but also with the cameras on them. Very few are fazed, even on the first day. When they’re asked a question, I’ve never seen one say, “For god’s sake, go away, I’m trying to bake something.”

Any hints about this year’s winner?

My lips are sealed! Ever since I infamously tweeted the winner from Bhutan, I’m super-cautious about not giving anything away.

PRUE ON THE FUTURE

What’s your next big adventure?



At the moment I’m really enjoying television, but I used to hate it. Back in the 70s, I did a lot but I was always scared and I didn’t like that everything was so heavily scripted. Of course, things are more free and easy now. I also loved the buzz of running my own catering company. I think it’s why I’ve enjoyed launching my own range of specs so much. I like the challenge of sorting out budgets and production and, of course, it’s lovely to have 72 pairs of glasses to choose from! SHOP PRUE'S GLASSES
